newsitem.title: BURUNDI: Aid agencies welcome easing of Burundi sanctions.
newsitem.headline: Aid agencies welcome easing of Burundi sanctions.

text.p: U.N. aid officals on Monday welcomed a decision by African countries to ease sanctions against Burundi, saying it had saved a programme to vaccinate nearly 200,000 children.

"I am pleased because everything UNICEF was requesting has been accepted. Now we can save our vaccination programme for 1996 and that is a positive thing," said Michel Sidibe, Burundi representative for the U.N. Children's Fund in Bujumbura.
He said vaccinations for 190,000 children had been under threat as UNICEF lacked fuel to keep vaccines cold.
Burundi was placed under sanctions by regional states after Tutsi leader Pierre Buyoya, a retired army major, seized power and ousted the Hutu president in an army coup on July 25.
A regional sanctions committee said it agreed at a meeting in Tanzania on Friday to allow U.N. flights to Burundi, road access to the land-locked nation for staff and permission to import some fuel.

It cleared U.N. agencies to import baby food and other essentials for infants and hospital patients subject to "strict verification and control arrangements." It also allowed imports of emergency medical and laboratory supplies and kerosene to keep vaccines cold.

But it said the steps should not undermine the "essence of sanctions" and noted Tutsi military ruler Pierre Buyoya had not met three conditions for ending sanctions -- restoring parliament, lifting a ban on political parties and immediate talks with Hutu rebel groups.
Sanctions have forced the army-appointed government to ration fuel and increasing prices of home-grown food because of higher transport costs.
More than 150,000 people have been killed in Burundi in a civil war and massacres since 1993, fuelling fears of bloodshed on a scale similar to neighbouring Rwanda's genocide in 1994.
Keeping up the pressure, Hutu rebels for a fourth time in two weeks destroyed a pylon for power lines to the capital, according to a senior official at the national power company.
Most of Bujumbura has had no power for two weeks. The power company produces only enough electricity for hospitals, water pumping and schools in the lakeside capital.
Martin Griffiths, director of the U.N. Department for Humanitarian Affairs, told Reuters in Nairobi the sanctions changes were very positive.
He said agencies might go back to the committee if there were other shortages -- such as food -- but for the moment the two main problems of fuel and access had been resolved.

The U.N. World Food Programme (WFP) said it was concerned about agriculture because imports of fertiliser and seeds were still banned. WFP Director Jean-Luc Siblot said that could make the majority Hutu population more dependent on aid.

"The embargo on fertilisers stands and it will have dramatic consequences on agricultural production soon," Siblot said. Thousands of tonnes of fertiliser and seeds destined for Burundi are impounded at Tanzania's port of Dar es Salaam.

Buyoya said on Saturday Julius Nyerere, the international mediator on Burundi, had agreed to organise a regional summit. But Tanzanian officials said no date had been set and it was doubtful that members of Buyoya's government would be invited.
